title: Gilson Kleina
text:
Gilson Kleina (born 30 March 1968) is a Brazilian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager, currently in charge of <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Ponte%20Preta">Ponte Preta</a>.
Managerial career.
Born in <a href="Curitiba">Curitiba</a>, Kleina started his career at <a href="Coritiba%20Football%20Club">Coritiba</a>'s youth setup, as a fitness coach. He later acted as <a href="Abel%20Braga">Abel Braga</a>'s assistant at the same club, also having stints at <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a> and <a href="Clube%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20Mineiro">Atléttico Mineiro</a>. His first managerial experience occurred in 2001, with <a href="Vila%20Nova%20Futebol%20Clube">Vila Nova</a>.
After another spell as Braga's assistant at <a href="Botafogo%20de%20Futebol%20e%20Regatas">Botafogo</a>, Kleina took over <a href="Iraty%20Sport%20Club">Iraty</a> in 2002, and subsequently was in charge of <a href="Crici%C3%BAma%20Esporte%20Clube">Criciúma</a>, <a href="Paran%C3%A1%20Clube">Paraná</a> (three stints), Iraty, <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Caldense">Caldense</a>, <a href="Cianorte%20Futebol%20Clube">Cianorte</a>, <a href="Paysandu%20Sport%20Club">Paysandu</a>, <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Coruripe">Coruripe</a>, <a href="Sociedade%20Esportiva%20do%20Gama">Gama</a>, <a href="Ipatinga%20Futebol%20Clube">Ipatinga</a>, <a href="Sociedade%20Esportiva%20e%20Recreativa%20Caxias%20do%20Sul">Caxias</a> and Vila Nova.
On 27 August 2009, Kleina signed with <a href="Duque%20de%20Caxias%20Futebol%20Clube">Duque de Caxias Futebol Clube</a>, as a replacement to <a href="Rodney%20Gon%C3%A7alves">Rodney Gonçalves</a>. After stints at <a href="Boavista%20Sport%20Club">Boavista</a> and Ipatinga, he returned to the club on 7 June 2010.
In November 2010, Kleina was appointed manager of <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Ponte%20Preta">Ponte Preta</a>. He achieved promotion from the <a href="Campeonato%20Brasileiro%20S%C3%A9rie%20B">Série B</a> in the end of the following year, taking the club to <a href="Campeonato%20Brasileiro%20S%C3%A9rie%20A">the main category</a> after a six-year absence.
On 19 September 2012, Kleina was named <a href="Sociedade%20Esportiva%20Palmeiras">Sociedade Esportiva Palmeiras</a> manager, in the place of fired <a href="Luiz%20Felipe%20Scolari">Luiz Felipe Scolari</a>. Despite <a href="2012%20Campeonato%20Brasileiro%20S%C3%A9rie%20A">suffering relegation</a>, he brought back the club to the first division as champions, but was still sacked on 8 May 2014.
On 13 August 2014, Kleina was appointed at the helm of <a href="Esporte%20Clube%20Bahia">Bahia</a>, but resigned just three months later. The following 24 March, he was announced at <a href="Ava%C3%AD%20FC">Avaí</a>.
On 11 December 2015, Kleina was presented at his first club Coritiba, now as first team manager. He left the club the following 2 June, and was named <a href="Goi%C3%A1s%20Esporte%20Clube">Goiás</a> manager on 5 September.
On 23 March 2017, Kleina returned to Ponte Preta, but was relieved from his duties on 16 September. On 16 October, he was named <a href="Associa%C3%A7%C3%A3o%20Chapecoense%20de%20Futebol">Chapecoense</a> manager.
Kleina was sacked by "Chape" on 6 August 2018, with the club seriously threatened with relegation. On 2 October, he returned to Ponte in the place of sacked <a href="Marcelo%20Chamusca">Marcelo Chamusca</a>, being sacked on 18 February 2020 after a poor start of <a href="2020%20Campeonato%20Brasileiro%20S%C3%A9rie%20B">the campaign</a>.
On 15 August 2020, Kleina was announced manager of <a href="Clube%20N%C3%A1utico%20Capibaribe">Náutico</a>, replacing <a href="Gilmar%20Dal%20Pozzo">Gilmar Dal Pozzo</a>. He returned to Ponte for a fifth spell on 28 May of the following year.
